intro: Draba pauciflora var. franklinii, commonly known as Franklin's dwarf whitlow grass, is a low-growing, herbaceous plant native to the alpine and subalpine regions of the western United States. It typically features a basal rosette of narrow, linear leaves and produces small, white to pale yellow flowers in early spring. The plant is adapted to harsh, cold environments and thrives in well-drained, rocky soils. Its flowering stems are usually less than 10 centimeters tall, and the flowers are clustered in dense, umbel-like inflorescences. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many flowering plants with characteristic cruciform petals.
